As a workaround, we copied the junit.jar to the jre/lib/ext of the installed jre
and we are also using the extClassLoader (perhaps the use of the extClassLoader
was the source all of our troubles).

This workaround appears to have fixed the problem, but we would prefer a
solution that would allow us to refer to the junit.jar in the eclipse plug-in
instead of the jre/lib/ext.  Is this possible?
Suspect that this is a JDT issue.  Moving...

Moving to PDE since they contribute the launch configuration for JUnit Plug-in 
testing.

Is org.junit one of the plugins selected on the Plugins tab of the launch 
configuration?

Yes ... see my original post:

"We have tried adding junit.jar as a required plug-in on the Plug-ins tab as
well as adding the junit.jar to the classpath via a VM Argument, but neither
have been successful."

The "Plug-ins tab" I was referring to was the tab on the launch configuration.

As noted in my second post, the problem was most like related to the fact that
we are using the following VM argument: "-Dosgi.parentClassloader-ext".  We have
to do this in order to use Java3D (whose jars are stored in the jre/ext/lib
directory of the installed VM)

I "solved" the problem by discovering that org.junit was not a *required 
plugin* of my test plugin. See bug #76074.

Right.

If your plugin uses JUnit code, then you must list org.junit as a dependency in your plug-in's manifest as you would with any other dependency.

that is why it is usually recommended to keep test code in a separate plug-in.

No action required here.
